posts.name: bardd
posts.cooked:
Recently I’ve come to realize that a lot of knowledge in FRC is “spoken wisdom” – passed down from person to person via conversation (or, at most, a lecture), usually within a team. I figure putting down this spoken wisdom in writing might help a lot of teams improve, and I suggest this thread as a place to collect it. So, what item of knowledge can you share? Looking for information in any field – mechanical, electrical, programming, control…

I’m splitting this to two threads, to make it easier for us to keep consistency in the level of knowledge we share. This thread is for “common” knowledge, i.e. information that most teams probably already have, and may help newer teams and\or otherwise less experienced (I’m sure a lot of teams lost a lot of “common” knowledge during Covid). For example, did you know that you could 3D print timing pulleys reliably? I didn’t. Based on what I’ve seen in competition, most of you probably did.

Please elaborate as much or as little as you can/want, from a full white paper to a single line, everything helps.

Looking forward to hearing your spoken wisdom! My contribution is in the first reply.

posts.name: bardd
posts.cooked:
If possible, avoid attaching a shaft to the same body in more than two points (i.e. bearings or hubs). A line passes through two points, and since every part/assembly has some tolerances, it is virtually impossible for three bearings/hubs to line up perfectly when mounted on the same body. If you try passing a shaft through three bearings, at best, assembly will be a struggle; at worst, the shaft will be stressed, and over time these stresses might cause it to fail.

(To be clear, when I say “three bearings”, I mean all three are mounted to the same body. A shaft will usually have at least four points of attachment, but to different bodies; for example, if a shaft connects an arm to the body of the robot, we might have two bearings mounted in the body of the robot and two hubs on the arm itself. That’s still only two points of attachment to each body.)

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
Torque is the product of force and distance.  So if you have a high-torque connection like the final joint in an arm, don’t use a shaft, use a big sprocket that’s bolted near the edges of it to the arm.

A sprocket+chain connection is a good choice for the final stage of something that might see a lot of external shock force applied (e.g. an arm that extends outside the robot).  Chain+sprocket has a lot more contact area than a gear tooth, so is going to be more tolerant to shock loads–and as stated above, also has less force applied in general if you follow the previous paragraph.

Single solenoids can still be used to actuate a double cylinder

Single solenoids can still be used to actuate a double cylinder

Find undersized aluminum hex shafts to fit your hex bearings and couplers since oxidization will increase shaft diameter and make it impossible to remove the bearings later

Find undersized aluminum hex shafts to fit your hex bearings and couplers since oxidization will increase shaft diameter and make it impossible to remove the bearings later

Never use PLA 3D printed material if you plan to demo your robot outdoors on a sunny day in the future

Never use PLA 3D printed material if you plan to demo your robot outdoors on a sunny day in the future

Ferrules will NOT work in the new REV pneumatics control module for solenoid power connections

Ferrules will NOT work in the new REV pneumatics control module for solenoid power connections

Don’t allow your redlines/775pro to be in a stall condition

Don’t allow your redlines/775pro to be in a stall condition

Don’t skimp on chassis strength by removing too much material.  Even with bumpers, the chassis can encounter hundreds of pounds of shear force and a misaligned chassis will be nothing but problems for your drivetrain.  Also it contributes to a low CG which always helps.

Don’t skimp on chassis strength by removing too much material.  Even with bumpers, the chassis can encounter hundreds of pounds of shear force and a misaligned chassis will be nothing but problems for your drivetrain.  Also it contributes to a low CG which always helps.

Never use philips head screws on your robot (electronic connectors can be an exception)

posts.name: kgzak
posts.cooked: when looking at match schedules, always remember that every match you are in has your robot on the alliance. (this can be good or bad depending on the robot)

posts.name: yadin
posts.cooked: When making a tank drive(also known as “kit drive”), the bigger the long to wide ratio is, the harder it will be for the robot to turn. that is, a very long and thin drivetrain will have a harder time turning.
De-bur and sand every part as it comes off the machine shop tool, and before it is assembled onto the robot.

posts.name: Giora Kornblau
posts.cooked:
lots of practice time is (in most cases) more important than fancy mechanisms.

keep it simple!

definition of “Simple” in this context: very high chances of finishing integration and testing on schedule, according to your team’s capabilities

posts.display_username: This isn't a game. Think about the repercussions.

posts.name: Crystal
posts.cooked:
1/2" hex shafts are a great solution for many but not all design problems. For very high load things with lots of potential bending forces, such as the main shaft of a long arm, you will want something designed for that load. You can use larger diameter, thin wall hollow tubing to achieve this.

Before there were solid COTS products to fill this niche (check out REV’s offerings, or the VersaRoller, etc), a decent enough solution would be to use 1.125" OD bushings and 1" OD or 7/8" OD hollow tube. This preserves compatibility with various COTS things that hold bearings while being much stronger in bending than hex shaft. With a thick enough wall (1/8")  you can even be just as strong in shear, but you generally don’t need to be and so you can save weight over hex shaft by going to 1/16" or so.

This is one of those things I’ll see veteran teams all had their own preferred solution for, but lots of younger teams will just use hex shafts everywhere, and end up with twisted and broken arms. Just something to keep in mind!

posts.name: 829 The Digital Goats Official Curmudgeon.
posts.cooked:
You need to keep track of weight starting day one. Use a spread sheet and calculate what things will weigh and eventually what they actually weigh.

Showing up at comp with an overweight robot can be a disaster.

posts.name: Christopher149
posts.cooked:
To have a chance of winning, your robot needs to play the game. It needs to have mechanisms that can complete the scoring tasks reliably enough, and be operated to actually complete those tasks.

It’s disappointing when you see robots not complete tasks they can do, or spend time doing non-tasks like:

Parking in the hangar in 2022

Spinning the control panel when your alliance hasn’t reached stage 2 capacity in 2020

Not parking under the generator switch in 2020 if there was enough room

Wandering around with an auto ball in 2014 so the alliance can’t start cycling

Shooting an auto ball over the truss in 2014 (that wasn’t worth anything, and see point above)

posts.name: wgorgen
posts.cooked:
‘Stealing from the best and inventing the rest’ is not really stealing.

Edit: I was asked to elaborate:

Basing the design of a mechanism on a similar design previously fielded by another team involves a lot of valuable learning. You need to spend the time to figure out why it worked, why it is a good choice for your robot and how it was constructed. You need to potentially adapt it to a different size game piece and to the rest of your robot. You may end up studying another team’s CAD model in the process and see details of how a design was built that will teach you new techniques for doing things that add to you knowledge. You may also study their code and learn about control system techniques and automation. Bottom line is that there is a lot of valuable growth and learning to be gained through the process of coping a successful design from the past.

posts.name: Brad L
posts.cooked:
One complete subsystem will function much better than two incomplete subsystems.

Or in the words of Ron Swanson
